Ergo Proxy has been highly appreciated by people whom I respect very much, so I decided to give it a try. Besides, it is often compared to Neon Genesis Evangelion in terms of mind-fuck, pardon my language, and as I think Eva is a masterpiece, I just had to watch Ergo Proxy.
Not that I regret my decision, but it wasn't worth it. Sorry, I don't get the hype around it. It is so mediocre for me, I can't even say.
The series' plot jumps at you right away from the very beginning, which leaves you a little bit astonished. Although as the series progresses, you getthe overall picture, bit I think Ergo Proxy tried to do too much at a time. There are too many things it wants to talk about, too many matter it wants to address. Besides, despite all the struggle, the plot is very banal. There is nothing original in it, not for me.


The best part of the series is the art. The sceneries, the characters - everything is well-adjusted to show the atmosphere of the world. Even thought it is done in very dark colours, which sometimes makes it difficult to watch it, it just feels right. I did notice a few problems with long-sots, such as eyes, which are on different levels, etc, but I think it's okay considering the overall beauty of the art.

Another point for the opening sequence, which is really-really beautiful.


The sound did nothing to me. Radiohead as the ED is cool and all, but does it really suit the subject and the mood? OP was decent, I've let it play a couple of times, but it's nothing like Mushishi opening or Elfen Lied's opening or Mononoke's opening.

The background music...was it there? It did literally nothing to me, which still makes it good, as it means it suited well the sequence.


The characters are the strong side of the anime as well. They are complex, they have their reasons and they develop.

Real is the girl-with-the-gun in the beginning. She is emotionless, she can't express her feelings, she loves to fight. She is a bit of bitch, if you ask me, in the beginning. But as the story develops, so does her character, and in the end we see a completely different Real, who "believes".

Vincent is actually a much more complex character, who has several layers, pun intended. At first we see a stupid-looking guy, whose eyes are always closed. I, for one, couldn't not wonder WHY THE HELL HE LOVES REAL? Thank God, at least that part of the plot was revealed later.

I absolutely loved Raul Creed. His character is unexpectedly human and has some surprises, which I can't talk about without spoiling everything.

Deadalus is another example of a background, but still a complex character. Pino is more of a child than any other human child in anime.


Concerning enjoyment - sorry, not at all. At first it was frankly boring, then it became average, but in the end it became boring again. I don't know why it turned out like this, because having such a plot and characters, it should have been so much better, but it wasn't.

The last few episodes seemed like they tried to cram a huge story in just a couple hours. It was an overload of information, which still seemed to say boring.


In fact, Ergo Proxy disappointed me greatly. No way I'm ever going to advice someone to watch it.

If I had to describe Ergo Proxy in the shortest way possible, I would call it the crowning jewel of my anime exploration thus far. It's a transcendent piece of art which needs to be viewed from a specific angle, else its glory cannot be grasped to the fullest - and this is by no means your typical rated-not-for-everyone statement or what not, a concept which I consider to be utterly ridiculous, simply because a universally accepted piece in the world of art doesn't exist. All of ye who proceed, do yourself a favor and abandon all objectivity.
First of all, Ergo Proxy falls into thecategory of more engaging shows, so if you're the type of person that dips into anime to alleviate stress caused by a hectic daily curriculum, this one will not yield satisfactory results for you. The plot is not easy to follow and lack of focus and/or wrong mindset will hamper your ability to observe its true motion, consequentially making it apparently lacking in substance, or even being non-existent. 


Before going into detail about various aspects of the show, I will try to describe it with tags or very short sentences that would get me hooked, to attract new potential fans, and at the same time save some time for the viewers that would probably end up disappointed with it. Obvious tags like cyberpunk, dystopia or sci-fi are obvious, hence excluded.


	- Dark, gloomy, implicit and often symbolic/metaphorical in expression, moderately slow progression

	- simple and not flashy art (sepia much?), ambiental soundtrack

	- emphasis on character development, philosophical content consistent to its own logic, sharp dialogue, exceptional and unique plot

	- almost completely void of action and humor

	- has a subtle and non-vulgar sense of beauty,  no conventional love stories or sexual expression to be found 

	- will likely require to be watched a second time to make perfect sense out of it


Audio and visual  


… blend in quite well with the story and enhance the atmosphere, but actually are one of the weaker points of the show individually. Personally I wouldn't mind if the animation was executed in greater detail. The art itself is undoubtedly creative and imaginative, heck, I had a Monad wallpaper on my phone for a while after I'd seen it the first time, but it's just that the technical aspect is a tad bit lackluster.

As I mentioned before, there's a lot of sepia, dark colours, bleak tones, in both the environment and character design. Pink or turquoise haired / high pitch voiced girls all died in the methane layer explosion's blast so they're nowhere to be found in the material presented to us. Regardless, such gimmicks were completely unnecessary in making each character's portrayal unique in their own way; whether they're Proxies, humans or AutoReivs.

The main protagonists are both beautiful, on the first glance Vince looks as if he suffered from the "Brock" syndrome (yes, Pokemon's, to clear any doubt), but soon enough the situation is rendered self-explanatory. 

The technology is skillfully conceptualized and consequentially the sekai it forms,  it all works out great unquestionably, but I'd like to point out just one more thing in this section that really stood out for me. I'm a big sucker for clothing and I really liked the style here - personally I found it to be Marc Jacobs kind of, with a Tom Ford note here and there.

As for the auditory aspect, I did like a couple of pieces and the ambiental background music was generally good, very seldom out of place. I just had a problem on a personal level - every mention of the name "Radiohead" brings about the memory of the Scott Tennorman incident so it cracks me up a bit. If not for that I might be able to take them seriously. Anyway, no points deducted for that because there's no harm in skipping the intros/outros or even muting them and synching whatever the hell you like with the video. 


The story and its characters


When I say might not be for you because the content is engaging or demanding, I'm not trying to make myself feel better thinking I possess some great intellectual capabilities or calling anyone out for their supposed lack thereof. Preferences aside, everyday living tempo differs for each individual at given time, and sometimes we all just need well.. Rest. Obviously, the question is not only what, but also when.

There's not a whole lot of yatta yatta, don't expect that at all. And to be honest, I prefer pausing to reflect upon the dialogue's meaning and its implications, to pausing just because I need more time to read the whole damn thing. I remember watching Tatami Galaxy and averaging around 30 pauses per episode. Frankly it adds zero value to the show, watching an arbitrarily sped-up version of what a show is supposed to be (30 mins of material shrunk to fit a 20 min frame) makes the whole experience an incoherent mess, i.e. a pauseful nuisance. How about switching the subtitles off and trying to figure out Japanese? Or even playing it backwards with 8-bit sound, the video off, while kneeling in a pile of bolts and nuts? Now that would be extreme.

Apologies for the rant but I just find it too sad seeing good stuff ruined by pretentious ideas. With that said, you won't find pretentiousness or pretense here, the story is told in a very subtle manner. Going into details about the fabula would quickly create openings for spoilers.

Long story short, you will be presented a vision of the future with a spice of a few premises on the edge of what we could label as "realistic". The way the concept of artificial intelligence has been dealt with is not revolutionary, but it's smart and at times, dare I say it, charming. Even some of the AutoReivs are more established as characters than a lot of shows' protagonists. In case of humans, for instance, you get to know the Regent pretty well, albeit he never said a damn word. Some characters were arguably more likeable than the other, but of course it all depends on your personal dose of neutrality. Ultimately they all served their purpose just the way they were. For the most part, humans and "cogito virus"-infected AutoReivs' "Raison d'etre" was shrouded in strong emotions, and every single one of them was memorable. 

Daedalus' possessiveness toward Re-l (Real) and envy toward Vincent for everything being centered around him led him to a fate he had anticipated. Re-l's curious and rebellious, nature, as well as an inexplicable attraction to Vincent pushed her out of the bubble of self-absorption she'd created, and ultimately shattered the barrier of his denial.

The power-hungry chief Raul and his forever devoted entourage Kristeva also formed an interesting and meaningful relationship. Actually, all of them were in a way, but for a reason I ought not to share here. Omnes viae "Ergo" ferrunt is as far as I can go before being obliged to hoist the infamous Spoilerian flag.

One of the show's most commonly mentioned descriptions is the one of a self-discovering journey, as it is quite obvious to the viewer from its early stages. In my opinion this was masterfully executed as well. The pacing, the variety in the source of information and modorum they're conveyed.. 

This analogy might sound out of place but I could go on and compare the whole thing to a catwalk-striptease with an acrobatic flick at the end of the runway (the latter referring to the "quiz episode" halfway through the show. Props for the brave effort, I didn't think it was brilliant but it came as a surprise that's for sure. 

Ergo Proxy does not attempt to fool you with cheap tricks like misleading clues or ambiguous information, luring you to jump to wrong conclusions then dumps a bucket of cold truth on your face like some silly police thriller perhaps would. Just enjoy yourselves as the grand Proxy design unravels before you, but keep in mind that stopping to ponder might result in being left behind.

(Do not read this review if you have not watched Ergo Proxy yet, all kind of spoilers are contained)
Hey guys! Before getting any further, I want to highlight from the very beginning that this is purely my opinion after finishing the show, not a summary or analysis.
During and after finishing Ergo Proxy (will be mentioned as EP), one thing kept popping up in my head: “THINK, till you manage your own answers to the following question: What is the meaning beyond your existence?” Although the best description of EP is (bleak), yet EP indeed left me with a smile! In other words, it made methink, and deeper think, until I got some hints to answer this question. This is one of the things that makes EP a pure perfection! 


Story (10\10)

The story takes place in a decayed world, abandoned by its creator, dehumanized by the corrupt authority, populated by robots with few humans who have no capacity to engender. All this make the perfect setting for Vincent and Re-l mental and empirical journey. The plot is strongly consistent, full of twists, and stimulates suspense to its highest levels. Deep characters are presented in a fragmentary way, having no more than the poor choice of moving forward to their unknown "for both characters and audience" fate. What makes the story even greater is the outstanding open ending, leaving you contemplating on the endless multiplicity of meanings. Most other open-ended shows rather end in a vague and dull manner. However, EP somehow tried to make a balance in this regard. In the final episode, it gave us solid glimpses about all characters' final act, but depending on the twists we witnessed in the story, you will never trust a final fixed answer! This multiplicity of meaning in EP is really exceptional and makes the story impressively splendid! The story axiomatically deserves a (10).


Characterization (10\10):

I dare say That EP has the best “character development” among all other shows I have ever watched. 

- Although (Vincent) has two split and distinct personalities, he is one of the most profound characters I've seen in a while, and it is his schizophrenic identity which makes him more interesting and enjoyable to observe. Dai Satō managed to show the deep inner development of the two personalities he has and this makes the characterization even greater. Moreover, Vincent raises the opaque existential questions that anyone might ask him\herself; all his psychological problems could face anyone of us. Even when he restored his memories as a Proxy, he became more mysterious - especially in his last sentence - and raised more questions instead of solving them. This portrays the curiosity of human nature for truth, yet Vincent somehow has found his peace of both soul and mind, and tranquil his inner struggle most marvelously. He was able to shock us with the paradox he is living. Despite all the hardships he lived, his weakness, his eagerness for truth, his psychological trauma and split identity, he was able to reconcile with these facts and to accepte his other side! He is nothing less than a spectacular character indeed.

- (Re-l), despite being annoying and a pain-in-the-ass at times, she proved somehow to be a genius character. Throughout the story, she proved how profound and strong she is by getting rid of the personality forced over her by society; also, She was able to change and move forward despite losing all her loved ones. By the end of the story, she succeeded not only in finding her own ultimate truth, but also in solving all dilemmas in the society she lives in. Re-l eventually triumphed over all her doubts and adversities, and that in fact transformed Re-l into a character that is more likeable. 

- (Ergo and the other Proxies), I will not say much about them. However, I think they are the aesthetic side of EP. Every one of us can define the meaning, function, essence of Proxy in his\her own way based on one’s beliefs, views, culture, values and way of thinking. There is a whole philosophy represented in them and I could write pages discussing about them, but I'm certain that they will not be nailed down to a definition that easily. The more you contemplate about the proxies, the more meaning they will have. This elusive concept in EP is something you cannot find anywhere. What else could a great anime have!

- (Pino), the humanized robot or “AutoReiv.” When comparing Pino with any other human in the show, she was able to sympathize with any other creature no matter how different it might be, which is something most humans in the real world cannot do, or maybe refuse to do. However, she was able to do this by having the “human feelings” after she has been infected with a soul. Therefore, does she highlight the value of human soul, or point out the degradation of our human feelings and sympathy? 

- (Raul and Daedalus) were also very interesting. Both of them immersed in a great despair, but they faced it each by his own way. Daedlaus surrendered while Raul kept fighting. Deadlaus, at the final act, showed signs of his diseased mentality as a kind of a tax of his genius, preferred to die by the side of his illusion, embodied by fake Re-l. Whereas, Raul chooses to die human, and fight the mighty proxy. Even after he failed, he kept moving, wounded and bleeding in search for Pino, symbolizing his insistence to remain human and transcend his hatred, defending his humanity though instinctively. Both were surprisingly thoughtful, and added different undertones on the show.

The rest characters were all well shaped and enjoyable, namely Iggy, Queen and Hoody.


Production (8\10)

Manglobe's animating in EP is sometimes tacky; characters do not look the same in different situations. Vincent is an exception of course; his variety of appearances served his identity disorder fabulously, but as for Re-l and other characters, their facial features might look very different from a scene to another. However, the animating of the ever-darkening sky, frozen sea, the barren environment and dreary landscape have done the fascinating job in making EP’s surreal atmosphere. The soundtracks were also magnificent, Yoshihiro successfuly created the nightmarish tone that EP induces. Every single piece of music in EP was a pure perfection. MONORAL’s Kiri is the most memorable opening song of all time. The voice acting is also bewitching, particularly the AutoReives and how they were able to sound like human and robot simultaneously. Iggy is the best example in this regard, especially when he has been infected with a free will.  


To conclude, Ergo Proxy is one of those anime that deserves your full score, your constant admiring. Indeed, I have never approached an anime more surrealistic and bizarre, yet tackles the psychological problems of ours most craftily. In every single re-watch you will discover something valuable and new. EP is the best embodiment of abundance of meaning.

Critic’s Log - Earthdate: January 26, 2015. Review #92: Ergo Proxy
When someone forms an opinion on something, They think therefore they are. I have reviewed a number of anime because I think therefore I am. Regardless if this sounds pretentious or not. Here is Ergo Proxy
The world has become largely uninhabitable over the course of time and now what remains of humanity exists inside large dome-like cities. When androids known as AutoReivs begin committing crimes and displaying a semblance of free will, Re-L Mayer begins investigating the cause. This takes her on an adventure that encourages her to ask deep philosophical questions aboutherself, her companions Vincent and Pino, as well as the world they live in.


Ergo Proxy is a Manglobe production and I have been enjoying some of their work as a studio. Samurai Champloo was pretty cool and nice to look at for the most part and Deadman Wonderland looked great. Ergo Proxy is a show worth mentioning in regards to Manglobe as a studio. This show looks great from start to finish. It does have its hiccups and inconsistencies  along the way but at least the shortcuts were at a minimal. Ergo Proxy just looks wonderful when it hits the right notes.  the opening visuals on the other hand are amazing. It is personally one of my Top 10 favorite openings. Really, I mean it. That is how much I liked this opening. With all due respect, the opening of this show is really worth looking at from episode to episode. The animation as a whole does stand out among the thousands out there. You wanna know something even more remarkable. The show has a blend of 2D animation for the character designs and some 3D CG Animation for like vehicles and other designs, and blended in just right unlike Studio GONZO whom are infamous for having their 3D animation stick out like a sore thumb for most of their shows. This is by far one of Manglobe’s best looking Animes.



The music by Yoshihiro Ike is kind of noteworthy because it does fit the show very well. The show is dark, dystopian, and desolate. The soundtrack fits the bill on this one. The soundtrack sounds like it would fit any film with a dystopian setting but I guess that would depend on the settings as well. It’s a shame that this is the only soundtrack I think Ike-san shines on. I have not seen Kuroko’s Basketball and I am now aware he does the soundtrack for that show. This is by far the best soundtrack I’ve heard from Yoshihiro Ike. The soundtrack knows when to hit the right notes and I’m glad it did its job just right. Now the intro and outro of Ergo Proxy is a rather fascinating topic on its own but some of you probably know where this is going but allow me to indulge in this moment because I share opinions on many aspects in a show and intros and outros are part of that too. The intro “Kiri” by Monoral is mind-blowing. Well… To an extent it can be seen as such. I did say the visuals looked amazing but the song itself was a surprise by looking up Monoral. Now the lyrics were in English and not Japanese as you can tell by the opening if you have seen it and heard the song. Monoral is not from America or any other country other than Japan. Monoral is a Japanese alternative rock band. Now the lead singer’s origins kind of explain why the song is in English with no instances of Engrish in it. Anis Shimada, the lead singer is Japanese-Moroccan and can speak Japanese, English, French, and Arabic. The other member, Ali Morizumi is Japanese-American. And yet in 2006, they belt out this song and it is just a rare treat when it comes to Japanese music and anime intros. The visuals and the intro song kick ass and I have good reason why it’s one of my favorite openings. Then there is the Closing theme. "Paranoid Android" by Radiohead. Before I got into this anime, I never heard Radiohead or the song Paranoid Android and I know, I should be ashamed of myself. You know what? It isn't my fault that I had lack of exposure to Radiohead. This I blame on radio stations for its lack of radio publicity. Thanks to Ergo Proxy, I have been enjoying Radiohead's work. The visuals in the Closing may not show much but that’s fine because the song fits the show. Ergo Proxy had interesting choices concerning its Opening and Closing and it succeeds. The soundtrack is great.



With Voice acting, the Japanese cast is mostly alright. Rie Saito is great as Re-L and I had no problem with her voice in this one. Koji Yusa is a bit of a down-note for me. I did not like parts of his performance as Vincent. Akiko Yajima is what I would expect with a character like Pino but she plays the role just fine. I don’t have much to say about the Japanese casting because the English Dub is very good in this show. Megan Hollingshead is great as Re-L. Liam O’Brien is a surprise as Vincent. Rachel Hircshfeld’s portrayal of Pino is also good too. Also, Travis Willingham, Patrick Seitz, and even Yuri Lowenthal are pretty good in the dub. Now the dub’s highlight without a doubt is Dameon Clarke who you may recognize so well as Scar from the original Fullmetal Alchemist anime. Dameon Clarke was fantastic in this one and it may be my favorite role of his.  I actually strongly prefer the dub when it comes to Ergo Proxy. The overall performance is outstanding, and Jonathan Klein is responsible for this dub and he also was ADR director for outstanding dubs such as Hellsing (even though that show was a bloody mess, but still had a great dub) and Paranoia Agent. Ergo Proxy is without a doubt one of his best ADR directions.



Now Ergo Proxy does sport some interesting characters if you are patient enough. Re-L and Vincent are fine in their own right and Pino is a nice character even if she’s pretty much there for the ride. Iggy was an interesting case, Daedelus also brought an interesting contribution to the plot, Raul is actually the only recurring character I have mixed feelings for. I hope you’ve at least seen the first 3 episodes for this show. Raul’s reaction to his wife and child’s...demise  was poorly executed. Raul was somewhat interesting but I had a difficult time believing his turmoil early on in the show. This was my only nitpick with the characters. The majority of how the characters are played out were excellent. I will give Ergo Proxy credit for this. The unique thing about Ergo Proxy is how Re-L seemed to be the main character when Vincent is really the most vital character of the show since he too is treated the same way Re-L is concerning the brightest spotlight. For the most part. The characters do not disappoint.


Now the overall story of Ergo Proxy is a completely different matter. I liked the mystery aspect early on in the show and I can say that I was not disappointed with the outcome of where the show was going. You know, the resolution. That was all fine and dandy. Now I just have one burning question for Dai Sato (the writer) and Shukou Murase (the director). What was the fucking point of the quiz show episode? I have no idea what was on Dai Sato and Shuko Murase’s minds when that bafflingly questionable quiz-show episode came into play. I should mention the director of Ergo Proxy. Shuko Murase was an interesting case. For those who don’t know, he was the character designer for Final Fantasy IX, a really good game and one of my favorite Final Fantasy games. It was his only video game contribution.  Check it out if you have the means to. Ergo Proxy is also his most recent directorial role in an anime followed by his first directorial debut, Witch Hunter ROBIN. He is not much of an Anime director but he has contributed for years as animation director, But his resume isn’t too big. I would consider Ergo Proxy to be ambitious at best because the dystopian settings, the philosophy, and character development were fascinating. Now I would have had a huge fondness of this anime if it didn’t have an open-ended conclusion. Just when things seemed like it was leading into more, the show just ends. Here’s an idea… If going back in time were possible. It would be nice if that bullshit game show episode never existed and have a solid final episode instead of rushing things in and leave it open in the end. Also, the pacing did suffer a bit in the middle with how slow it was going. It speeds up near the end where I went from intrigued by this show to scratching my head at the end. Having its loose ends left open made the final destination of Ergo Proxy underwhelming. Like I said before, I found Ergo Proxy to be ambitious whereas some people claim it to be pretentious. I can see where they are coming from but the reason I find it ambitious is because for an anime with a dystopian setting. This was a unique anime to sit through. When the ending was all said and done, I just felt like the whole thing became underwhelming. If there is one thing pretentious about Ergo Proxy, it is that it attempts to be smart and deep. At times, it did succeed. Where Ergo Proxy falls flat is that it could have had a central plot but it wanders off by exploring other concepts which some were promising and some were just...questionable. As for the Raison d’etre of Ergo Proxy...I will say it one last time for this review. I think it is an ambitious anime that actually succeeds in getting the viewer intrigued in what Ergo Proxy offers without it being very pretentious. The viewer is likely to accept that Ergo Proxy is not perfect yet anything made by human hands is not perfect. We think therefore we are. The creators of Ergo Proxy put some thought in this one because they think therefore they are. I will say that the experience of this anime by other people than me will differ due to the nature of this anime. I say it because I think therefore I am…. Okay, that’s enough with my pretentious in-joke because it doesn’t add up and  that’s all I got for this review.



Ergo Proxy was originally available by Geneon and the show did go out of print but don’t you worry. It was made available once more when Funimation came along, rescued it from being out of print and it is now available by Funimation. A manga called “Ergo Proxy: Centzon Hitchers and Undertaker” by Yumiko Haro was never brought in stateside.



With that out of the way… Ergo Proxy is a unique series with its dark, desolate, dystopian settings. It does explore the human condition to a degree but does explore other concepts which some hit well and some miss. It does have a great utilization in its soundtrack and it does have great characterization even though I had some mixed feelings with a certain supporting character early on. Where it does have its issues is its inconsistent animation at times even though it looks fantastic during big moments. It still had ambition and it tried its damnedest without falling flat on its face and giving up halfway or even at the end. It was underwhelming with its conclusion but there are far worse conclusions. Some I’ve already witnessed. A little bit more would be nice with Ergo Proxy, but it is what it is therefore, it exists.



With everything said and done, I give Ergo Proxy a 8 out of 10, it is VERY GOOD!

(OVERALL REVEIW – mainly about my concerns with the anime): 
I was honestly very unsure as to whether I could write an "intellectual" review that Ergo Proxy deserves, so I have to apologise beforehand if my analysis is lacking in depth and understanding of this anime. Having debated between rating this an eight or a seven for about ten minutes after finishing the last episode, I finally settled on the latter purely based on my own biases. The skepticism about this show is understandable – it is an engaging, thought-provoking show which reminded me why I love this medium of entertainment (cyberpunk mysteries, not justtsundere cat girls, unnatural hair colours, or child soldiers in a post-apocalyptic setting). 


Yet at the same time Ergo Proxy is disjointed, doubtable, and, most of the time, downright weird. Many reviews on MAL has already broken down the anime nicely, so I will just discuss primarily my main concern with this show, which was the execution of events. Some episodic events were done to engage the audience with a backstory told completely differently from the norm (i.e. almost "breaking their own 4th wall", in a sense). However, while diverging from clichés of anime has a healthy tick of approval from me, I acknowledge that I, as an individual, have an average intelligence, and found it difficult to grasp the fundamental basics of half the dialogue the characters engaged in. Most philosophical questions asked seemed repetitive and said solely for the purpose of sounding "deep" – for example, "Cogito, Ergo Sum" (I think, therefore I am) is the basis and said dominant philosophical debate for the entirety of the show – but I fear the primary fault lies with the English subtitles, which may have lacked the intellect to express the colourful language of Japanese spoken.


I find the plot itself questionable. The show is very experimental, indulging in many different kinds of genres which they pull off surprisingly effortlessly. However, I must point out a plot hole with the robots ("the AutoReivs"), more so with the ones that are infected with a virus that gives them a "soul", allowing them to experience emotions. This is neither explained nor fully explored in detail: the explanation is vague, and inconsistent with scientific reasoning.


It was rather incomprehensible to follow their thought and logic, constantly asking myself questions such as "How is it possible for a man-made machine to suddenly posses a 'soul'? Where does it come from?" When one watches Ergo Proxy, one must remember that this show also falls under the category "sic-fi", i.e. Science Fiction. Therefore, I must also point out that I am one person: my argument is not a theory or proven but an opinion, rather than truth.  


The characters, simply put, are brilliant. Not perfect, of course, but brilliant nonetheless. That does not necessarily mean you will like them straight of the bat. Re-L (Lil is a fansub mistake), is one badass female lead, but spoilt by her social status and is seemingly detached from experiencing emotions. Vincent Law appears to be a disappointment for a male lead – a faceless, generic man with a submissive personality. However, both undergo major character development, which is actually shown to the audience rather than done off screen (i.e. they do not somehow miraculously become formidably impressive persons in the middle of the series for no particular reasons). 


The plot itself is very unique, and as mentioned before, unrealistic for our generation but thought-inspiring. As for music: one does not simply skip the OP of Ergo Proxy (it's sung in English and I didn't skip over it once during all 23 episodes). 


Personal note: I highly recommend solely shoujo/harem/shounen/ecchi genre watchers (and the like) to stray away from this. You may not necessarily like it nor understand it, and I myself admit this is not an anime for everyone, including myself. Despite being a fan of the likes of cyberpunk/psychological/dark fantasy genres, I found that for the majority of the time I was feeling "dafuq" or "hahahahhaahha ok ¿¿¿" and alas, did not come to fully embrace this hidden gem in the anime world, Ergo Proxy. But if you find the first episode engaging, then please stick with it to the bitter end – it is simply one hell of a ride.

I actually began watching EP over a year ago and stopped after the 6th episode.  Since I recently finished and thoroughly enjoyed Michiko to Hatchin, I thought I’d give Manglobe another chance and thus returned to Ergo and finally completed the series.
I come away with the same frustrations I had when I entered this world so long ago.  Not only is the plot drenched in philosophy but the gaps in resolution and misguided episodes continue to way heavy after viewing.  I’ll begin with the positives.  The atmosphere and mood of this series is beyond exceptional.  The muted color palette workswell with the sterile “city” landscapes, which contrast well with the more “deconstructed” environments.  The character designs are distinct and beautiful.  Re-l Mayer (the lead) deserves iconic status in the realm of cyberpunk Goth.  And the Proxy’s are a wonderful reminder of Alberto Giacometti’s work.  Both beautiful yet disturbing.


The easiest way to categorize it is: Bladerunner meets film noir meets GitS.  You’re instantly thrown into the mystery and introduced to all the main characters by the end of the first 20 minutes.  The pacing, music, and plot moves well into the 3rd episode but that’s where the trouble begins to rear its ugly head.   


By the 4th episode, the pacing comes to a crawl and during this second viewing, I realized what was missing for me: a sense of humor.  I don’t expect or need slapstick but for such a dark story, I expect some levity to help ease some of the more depressing stuff.  And EP has some pretty depressing stuff going on.  If you’re willing to move on (like I did the 2nd time around) the “who done it” mystery turns into a literal journey across the Earth to find the answers and back again.   Midway through, the serial turns episodic and you get these 20 minute 1 timers that are there to help the viewer discover bits of the truth.  Some are more successful than others and without spoiling anything, the infamous “game show” episode is obviously vital in understanding more about the history and depth of the story.  But what can easily be credited as “inventive” can also come across as self-indulgent.  They walk a very thin line before coming back to the main story arc.


Ergo Proxy has been described as a “mind f**k” and I often wondered if I would have been better off stoned while watching some of the more eccentric episodes.  But the truth is, the series made a conscious decision in prioritizing theme over character.  That sense of humor I was looking for comes about mid-season.  So do some more personal story lines, but it’s a little too late and the conclusion is packed into the last 2 episodes.  So after the crawl, I was rushed into an ending that still left a lot of answers unresolved.  


I’m not one of those people that needs everything wrapped up in a pretty bow.   The philosophizing doesn’t bother me (as I do prefer stories that demand me to think) and there are some truly memorable scenes sprinkled throughout the series, but when very specific and sometimes important plot points are either ignored or unanswered, it leaves a bad taste in my mouth.  Although I have to recommend Ergo Proxy as a ground breaking series in terms of design, mood, and execution, it’s ultimate failure is when it demands the audience's absolute attention to follow every crumb and trail.  And unfortunately, some of those trails lead you to an incomplete story.

This Review Is My Masterpiece, My Design, Gaze Upon My Mona Lisa . . . 
THE BEGINNING:
Watching Ergo Proxy is like picking up your 'to-go' order from your favorite Asian food restaurant, getting back to the privacy of your own home so you can gobble it down without any unnecessary onlookers quickly becomes your first priority as soon as the bag is put in your hand. Much like the way I demolished Ergo Proxy in one sitting (literally one sitting, I didn't even get up once to go pee) 
Now you've finished your meal and you pull out your fortune cookie from the bag, .. . . . you're excited because this is the good fortune cookie brand, not the one that tastes like a stale tortilla chip dragged through honey. You crack open your cookie, but alas you see no fortune. You feel betrayed and lied too. You grew up knowing that when you crack the cookie you get the little piece of paper that eventually becomes pocket lint after 3 washes in your jeans. But today your lord has forsaken you, NO FUTURE POCKET LINT FOR YOU!\n\n
THE MIDDLE TO ENDING:\n
This same feeling of utter betrayal and loss is the basic premises for Proxy, the anime version of an empty fortune cookie. Where what you grew up knowing to be true is turned upside down, growing fears and subconscious suspicions are revealed to be true. Emptiness, destruction, Isolation, endless cycles of pain and loss, all because of someone else's decision to not do their job correctly.\n\n
THE VERY END:\n
You pop the whole cursed fortune cookie in your mouth and begin to chew, making a mental note that this is what broken dreams taste like, and never to forget that taste . . . .BUT WAIT!!!! You realize the cookie actually does taste funny and you spit out something with a funny texture . . . . . . . .\n
YOUR MISSING FORTUNE!! Right when you were about to give up all hope, you open the microscopic, now soggy paper to take a look, it says;\n
"You Will . . . " but the rest of the sentence is illegible sue to smearing ink. You are about to fall again and sadden over what you could have had if things were done differently, but then you stop yourself, and remember how worse the feeling of no fortune was. You look at your "You Will" fortune and realize it's better than any other fortune in the world, because it is left open to your interpretation, it is whatever you want it to be.\n\n
The act of creation through observation . . . .I am not even remotely exaggerating or embellishing facts, that internal emotional roller coaster journey you and I just went through is pretty much EXACTLY what it is like to watch Ergo Proxy. Sure to someone only watching me on the surface I look like a hungry idiot who almost ate a piece of paper, But to you, . . . . who observed beneath the surface and saw a  whole array of emotions, realizations, and a sort of Revolution and/or Revelation take place.\n
 You know, therefore you are. . . . . . . going to check fortune cookies twice from now on!

**THIS REVIEW CONTAINS VAGUELY PRESENTED SPOILERS**
This is the show that dethroned Cowboy Bebop as my favorite anime and show of all time, but it is absolutely not a show that everyone will be able to stomach. As for me, I adore nearly every single bit of Ergo Proxy to bits.
Story:
This is a story that does not hold your hand, if that wasn't obvious enough. A better description would be that it appears as a figure in the shadows that you can barely see and must follow along. And for that exact reason, this is a show that you can only appreciate for its entire beingon a rewatch.


Easily the most divisive part of the reception to this show, the story of Ergo Proxy is misleading, often unpredictable, filled with foreshadowing, symbolism, techniques that will bend your mind for better or worse depending on your taste, symbolism, philosophy, mystery and symbolism. Did I mention there's a lot of symbolism in this show?


Each episode flows into the next with rare occasions of episodes that primarily serve as a standalone story on the main group's journey, for examples episodes 14 and 19. While neither of these episodes are necessarily important to the overall story and goals of the characters, all of the episodes do serve some purpose, in character development or otherwise.


The pacing of the story may leave something to be desired for some, as the first few episodes tend to not move much of a plot outside of the driving question Re-l is looking to answer. After episode 3, the real story and main setting of the story is put into play. I personally loved the first three episodes, as they give an introspective look at just how the society of Romdeau is, thought not why, which gives another driving question to the story, as well as how Re-l's mind works and how that aspect of her character plays into the story.


As a mystery anime, this entire show revolves around questions. Questions, questions, questions. What are the proxies? Who is Vincent Law? Why is Romdeau the way it is? Most of the questions asked by this show and in turn by the viewer are answered directly, some more so in the viewer's own thoughts, as well as implications that may not be as easy to catch onto as one may think. In that respect it may be easy to call it something of an Evangelion, or a Lain.


The only minor complaint that I have for the ending of this show is that it feels like it could have a few minor fixes to prevent the one thing that I would say is the least common tone in the entirety of the series - cheesiness. Some of the line delivery in the last four or so minutes leaves something to be desired, at least in the dub, and the ending itself is left vague. "What does the last shot mean?" "What's that character going to do?"


Overall, I'd give the story a 10/10. It is not without flaw, nothing can be, but the flaws I saw were almost all in the presence of my first watch only, as I was left almost angry at the fact that there were so many confusing parts of the presentation of the ideas, scenes, and lines. But as I said earlier, this show is phenomenally better on rewatch - and I had already given the show a 10/10 on first watch anyway.


Art:


Another well-known aspect of Ergo Proxy is the consistent quality of the art and animation shown throughout. Nearly every episode has fluid, well-drawn shots with some exceptions.


Character design is something that Ergo Proxy excels at. Every character, even minor background characters, feel unique and realistic. Re-l Mayer shows off a goth look befitting of her attitude, and a properly stern face to fit. Vincent Law's outfit is a normal worker's set of clothing for AutoReiv disposal, but as the story progresses he becomes more and more disheveled and less like he's trying to impress someone and more like he's just trying to survive. Pino is the one thing keeping the show from drifting too heavily into grim-darkness and her cute, childlike attire fits perfectly, as well as some (excusably) unrealistically adorable facial features. Raul Creed's attitude shifting throughout the story shows that the professional, stoic outfit of a security chief can fit just as well on a man hellbent on revenge. Daedalus Yumeno's boyish appearance befits the unsuspecting development he ensues.


The issue with the animation of Ergo Proxy is that it shows off some things -too- well, and that makes the less than greatly animated episodes rather glaring. If one were to compare episode 9, an episode rife with beauty, to episode 16, which shows absolutely no major plot developments outside of character development for Re-l, they would find that there's little comparison in quality, for obvious reasons. The animation is consistently great, but not consistent enough, and is why it gets a 9/10.


Sound:


As for voice actors, I can only say my opinions on the English dub, as that is all I have presently seen. And boy, are they fantastic.


Liam O'Brien as Vincent portrays a man who pushes himself to continue surviving and searching, and the gravelly voice put on contrasts the way he originally shows himself as an earnest and shy man beautifully. Megan Hollingshead delivers the bitter and cold tone that Re-l uses to show her attitude perfectly. And as her icy shell defrosts, it slowly becomes more and more casual and less, for lack of a better word, bitchy. Rachel Hirschfeld's part as Pino is the only member of the main cast who doesn't consistently shine as brightly as the other two voice actors, but nonetheless performs in a stellar way. The faults mostly stem from scenes where Pino is yelling as she runs away or falls, as they tend to fall flat on their face instead of showing the fear and worry you'd want from a suspenseful, dangerous scene. Otherwise, however, the tone of a precocious little girl is nailed right in the head by Pino's voice.


Patrick Seitz' range of emotions from smugness to disdain to fear to rage shows especially well in Raul Creed's tenacious, unpredictable character. Yuri Lowenthal's typecasting as a kid hero comes in handy in the performance of Daedalus Yumeno, subverting the well-intentioned tone he begins the series with as well as complimenting the character's design.


Minor characters often get varying voices, typically average at least, though some characters also stand out as either very high quality or... embarrassing. This shows well in the commune's Quinn and Timothy. Quinn's voice actress delivers the somewhat snarky, independent personality across to the viewer in spades. Her son, Timothy, on the other hand, stands out from every other voice in the entire show as awkward, flat, and even laughable. Luckily, he's the outlier.


The soundtrack of the show conveys the mysterious, dark tone of Ergo Proxy  incredibly well, primarily via ambient tracks that instill a primal sense of fear, discomfort even. Easily one of the standout aspects of the show for some. And to make matters plenty better, the opening theme is an alternative slow jam that not only stands out from the rest of the soundtrack but fits alongside it perfectly. And if you're a Radiohead fan like I am, you'd be delighted to know that Paranoid Android is the ending theme, and there is no other song that fits more.


As a result of the undeniably amazing soundtrack and consistently well-voiced characters, I can only give the sound a 10/10.


Character:


Every character in this show has massive development intertwined with the events of the story, and it shows in spades with flying colors - easily the best part of the show in my opinion.


This is not a show with a clear villain outside of the main cast's own curiosity, though nearly everyone does some morally questionable things along the way, the cast in Romdeau particularly. It'd be hard to talk about any of the characters and their development without spoiling every part of the plot, so I will leave it at the fact that the characters are a 10/10.


Enjoyment:


As I've mentioned before, this is a mystery anime comparable to Evangelion and Lain. Very little will be clear at first, and that is, in my experience, what drives many people to decide that the odd taste in their mouth after watching this show was bad. And that's fine, not everyone wants their shows to be complicated. But if one is the type of watcher who tries their hardest to think on and think back on every event that happened in the show, they would probably find a lot of enjoyment in a show like this. This especially goes for rewatchers. 


I'd like to bring special attention to my father, who has only ever seen four anime in his life, those being Speed Racer (Mach GoGoGo) as a child, Cowboy Bebop, Death Note, and Ergo Proxy, the latter three still not being shows he has completed watching. All of those shows are top-notch according to him, and he isn't the type to care much for anime. This is a show mature and universally enjoyable enough that you can show it to anybody who likes to search for the answers to questions.


Because I was in the shoes of the people who were confused and bitter about said confusion for multiple points during the series, especially episodes 11 and 20, I can't give Ergo Proxy a 10 for enjoyment. It's not a show for everyone, obviously. But because I adored it so much eventually, I'll settle for a 9/10.


Overall:


This is show is easily one of the most underrated pieces of media I've ever had the luck to watch. Every facet of the show imaginable is outstanding to me and I can only give it a 10/10.

I just finished Ergo Proxy, and it's one of the most mediocre psychological thrillers I've ever seen. There have been so many other shows that do this formula better since Ergo Proxy has aired and I have no idea why so many people hold this series in such a high regard. Perhaps they don't know what else is out there...
~Story~
Ergo Proxy's story is a tale of length, such length that it drags out into this array of hogwash that equates to pigeon poop on your car's mirrors. AKA, you don't have a clue what's going on. Which in turn is fine, a show that makesyou think is perfect. However, the formula is extremely disappointing. 

Going into this show I was excited, it looked very Cyberpunk(esk) to me, a perfect society, robots called AutoReivs, it seemed to have me fully engaged by episode 3. Then everything changed.

 What I thought was going to be a cyberpunk crime psychological thriller turned into something that perhaps The Chronicles of Riddick fans would enjoy instead.

 Ergo Proxy had taken a horrible turn, as if it had just given up. It provided so much action within those first few episodes and then it decided "this is enough time to slow down", which was completely unnecessary. After this it began to drag on, and on, and on...until I was completely disinterested, put the show on hold for a few months and watched it on and off. It was torture to watch, but I couldn't look away; one can't look away from a plane crash.

After episode 12 the show's plot tried to get a little deeper in the psychological department. One episode, (the first about the multiple Lil's and Vincent's) really had me engaged. This is what I wanted to see, not this previous predictable shell of everything I had seen before. However, this formula stayed the same until the conclusion of the series, which was extremely disappointing. So many other shows have done this better, Serial Experiments Lain for example, even Madoka Magica.

 Ergo Proxy went on for far too long, it could have been made into a better show with a limit of 12 or 13 episodes. Instead we got too long of a show, not enough explanation, and a lackluster ending.


~Art~

Not much to say here.

The animation seemed very 'stilted' and hard to relate to from a human perspective. During episode 19 I confirmed this due to the animals being drawn better than humans and AutoReivs in every aspect possible!

The 'domed' city is hardly ever shown, all but a simple shopping mall or a road. If I don't know where I am how do I to relate to the situation? Also, the dead world outside the dome was meek and depressing, never changing, boring.


~Sound~

The OP was wonderful, the music matched the foreshadowing of the show in a great way.

The ED, I personally think they should have picked Karma Police as a Radiohead song and not Paranoid Android.

Ergo Proxy tried to develop characters but failed miserably. There is no indication of emotion other than either distress, whining or sadness emitted from themselves.

Vincent is a whiny confused Shinji-clone who doesn't know what's going on the entire show until the last episode.

Lil is an extremely hard character to relate to and one I do not feel exists in the real world. No 19 year old has that level of maturity.

Pino is just there for the ride, not really needed.


~Enjoyment~

Forced, sake in hand, forced myself to finish it so I could dismantle it properly. 


~Overall~

It's been done better than this, much better.

Stream it, instead of buying it.

"All those who wander in the darkness seek the light, but when they reach the light, they turn away their eyes from the blinding glare."-Kazkis proxy
Ergo Proxy is a cyberpunk, suspense, sci-fiction anime show with LOTS of deeper philosophical dialogues and scenes. Featuring robots that kill, a government nobody recognizes, and romance between a commoner and a princess, Ergo Proxy leaves you confused and enlightened at the same time.
Story : 
The themes in this anime raise important, self reflecting questions which we ordinarily wouldn't even think about. The story is full of cliffhangers, and that is what makes this anime so interesting. It allows usto fill in the gaps using our own imagination. The story begins with Re-L mayer, the daughter of Romdeau's regent and her entourage - an AutoReiv called Iggy- investigating a virus called cogito virus that infects AutoReiv, essentially giving them human-like awareness. But all this changes when she comes across a deeper conspiracy involving beings called Proxies. This is where the anime completely grips the viewer. Throughout the show, we are left dumbfounded about these proxies. Humanoid figures with god like powers is a strange addition to a sci-fiction story, and yet that is what makes the twist so interesting. Oh, and how can I forget! Our main hero isn't Re-L Mayer. Its an immigrant mechanic by the name of Vincent Law who suffers from split personalities. One is our vincent, and the other is, well, find out for yourself. This series does involve some boring parts including a filler or two, but reflecting upon them after watching the series makes you realize that they were essential parts of the plot. Psychological anime generally focus on the mental state of the protagonist. However, Ergo Proxy takes a different turn, focusing instead on every character realizing his/her Raison d'être - or, reason for existence. The story is straightforward, yet twisted. Philosophy aside, the plot itself is entertaining and beautifully executed. Every episode arouses our curiosity, and when this curiosity is satiated, it creates even more questions. Sometimes, we are left at the edge of our seats, biting our nails and sweating all over, and other times, we are yawning with boredom. It get frustrating when a boring scene is dragged on and on, but these mundane episodes create a thirst for action and more intense scenes, and Ergo Proxy immediately obliges, which made watching this anime a delightful  experience.


Sound And Animation : 


This anime consists of two soundtracks, both by Yoshihiro Ike, The opening theme leaves a beautiful, mysterious impression on the mind, making the story quiet fascinating. The ending leaves an enigmatic impression, helping you retrospect about everything you have just seen/heard. Yoshihiro Iks's music brings out Ergo Proxy's dark theme in light-toned music and the contradiction helps deepen this anime's psychological impact even more. The art always justifies the story as whole and not individual characters. As I said, viewers are totally dumbfounded about the true nature of the proxies. Every time Re-l encounters a proxy, the face of the proxy isn't clearly shown. The head is often hidden in the darkness of the proxy's hair, and this artistic style helps mystify the proxy's persona. As long as the true nature of proxies are hidden, they are shrouded in sloppy art that does no justice to their characters. However, when the answers regarding the proxies have been satisfactorily answered, their faces are clearly unveiled. Re-l is depicted as a beautiful and fiercely independent woman and her gorgeous eyes makes her character even more charismatic. The proxy vs proxy fight scenes are always intense and fast, and instead of focusing on prodigious moves and surprising blows, they serve mainly to show the Ergo proxy's true strength. The plot twists are full of suspense as they are, the animation intensifies these twists, making your heart beat run.


Characters : 


The characters have been bought out beautifully. Re-l is the beautiful, proud, arrogant and nosy grand daughter of Romdeau's ruler. In spite of being an excellent officer, she is always frozen with fear whenever she encounters a proxy. Its confusing, yet, in Re-l's words, she finds herself "strangely drawn to the proxies". The reason isn't revealed until the very end, but when it is, it makes an interesting twist. 

Vincent Law is a poor immigrant, who falls in love with Re-l. Suffering from amnesia, he travels from dome to dome until, travelling with Re-l and Pino, they reach Mosk, his home-dome, in an attempt to recover his lost memories. When Vincent finally remembers, he suffers from an internal conflict, with who-he-wants-to-be trying to defeat-who he-was. this fight takes a physical form, making an interesting action scene. 

Pino is the cute AutoReiv infected by the cogito virus. Whenever the anime takes a depressing turn, she lights up the screen with her optimistic attitude and cute smile. Although in many scenes, the dark theme contradicts her light attitude, it still makes a hopeful setting, making the viewers yearn for more.

Iggy is the caring and loving entourage of Re-l who, as it turns out is the spy cam of Re-l's grandfather. From the beginning he is seen as nothing but a programmed robot. Viewers would usually turn a blind eye to the insults Re-l throws at him. but we are shown yet another aspect of humanity, when Iggy gets infected by the cogito virus. The feelings of anger, jealousy and betrayal are shown by an expressionless robot and even though we can't see the anger, it is so evident in Iggy's actions that the we can't help but appreciate the irony of an empathetic robot.


Overall : 


Many complain of the confusing story line and I guess it is because they get caught up in the philosophy of this anime. True, this is psychologically gripping, but the charisma of this anime is lost if we thing too much about the comments and dialogues made. The ending is quite abrupt, but that's another reason why I enjoyed this anime so much. After completing this, I spent days thinking about what happens next, and essentially ended in a lovely ending that I made. This is part of the reason why I don't think this anime needs a 2nd season. The second season takes place mentally and that  is what makes this anime so magnetic. A perfect start, a perfect end, that's Ergo Proxy.

This was by far one of the most surprisingly good anime series, that I came across. I remember that this was recommended to me by a friend, and I wasn't too sure about it at first. The art alone was something that I've never came across. It was something completely different, compared to most anime styles. You could say that perhaps it was more of an American styled anime, rather than a Japanese one. So let me get to the main points now:   
Story:The story has interesting cyberpunk theme. It's something that I have not come across before, and it was a pleasantsurprise to me. The fact that from the very firs episode, there was already action going on, and we see Re-l already dealing with "monsters" is what made me go through the entire series.   


Sound:The background soundtrack is very suiting for the series. It's atmospheric, and in some sense dark, really brining out the theme of the show. 


Characters: I admire the main character (like I usually do for most series ahaha...), and her strong will. The fact that she's a great female leading character is really admirable. I do have to say that she is by far one of the best female leading characters that I have came across. She pretty much breaks the usual "strong male character", that is found in most anime's, and proves that female character's are also great in major roles, like Re-l. Vincent was also an interesting character. He had an interesting background, and the way he acted was also a bit different in comparison to most major male characters.

Initially, I felt pretty sure this would become one of my favorites: great art, good setting, interesting plot-hooks.
The problem is that after a few episodes it throws every appeal out. You think it will be a sort of Aeon-Flux with more demons and film noir intrigue, instead trek out into the wasteland to power up and fight the monster of the week.
The show eventually comes full circle, but by the end it felt like there was mostly filler. You are always waiting for more characterization, only to have exposition dumped on you in the 11th hour. This is NOT how you get people invested inthe story.\n\n
Good twists enhance your enjoyment on repeated watching, but the characters are still dead flat, it is impossible to watch a second time much less recommend a first viewing.

So Ergo Proxy is probably more suited towards those who have watched a lot of anime and can appreciate different aspects of the darker, psychological genre. To the people who plan to watch this:
1. Be prepared for very unique and beautiful art. The animators in Ergo Proxy pretty much discarded the stereotypical large-eyes, bright colors drawing style of most anime and substituted it for more realistic and subtly beautiful art.
2. Don't get depressed easily. This anime is mostly gray and black (expect for Re-L's eyeshadow). However, that also makes the rare moments with bright color stand out even more. You'll see.
3. Don't get frustrated. Someof the characters in the story may frustrate the viewer a LOT, but grit your teeth and pull through. The ending is worth it.\n\n
4. Don't watch this if you don't think you can handle it. This anime has a lot of psychological undertones and is honestly pretty dark and controversial. If you're a die-hard lover of romcoms and cannot handle gore or that kind of "stuff" then I suggest you stay away from Ergo Proxy.\n\n
5. Enjoy! Although everything I just wrote sounds really depressing, Ergo Proxy is a must-watch for the seasoned viewer. The elements of mystery and mindblowing story really draw you in, and like I said, the ending is worth the twenty-something episode wait. (I watched the whole series in one day... oops).

This is a perfect 10.
The twists and turns of Vincent Law's personality and how he matures over the course of the series, the way Lil Mayar is used as a medium to progress aspects of Romdeau and how Vincent Law is connected to it, and the remaining characters of this series (Dedalus, Raul, Iggy, Pino, Kristeva, Monad, Ergo, and the minor characters in between) are handled with pin-point accuracy in my opinion. Nobody stays more than their needed to be, and nobody is under-represented.
My personal favourite in the series was episode 11, where the arguments used in helping Vincent Law understand himself, and I thinkthat the whole key of this series lies in that episode.


Another aspect which I loved of this anime was its artstyle - although dark and gritty, it does give a wonderful contrast to the situation and the settings in which the anime takes place: the way the transitions happens between Romdeau (or for that matter, any other city outside of Romdeau) and the outside world which is in between cities, makes it really sublime. They not only add to the progression of the series, they also add to the environment and the feel of the anime. For me, this is a really well founded anime.


Although this is nitpicking, I think that another aspect which gives this anime a good kick is the subtle influx of philosophical constructs and arguments, as well as the use of literary references. You'll get what I mean once you watch it - oh, and on a conclusion, I think that the best character would be Pino. And I praise her voice acting in the Japanese version.


In conclusion, its a good anime. Amongst the best I've seen thus far.

Ergo Proxy is mindfuck. I'm serious. If you don't want to be constantly doushite-ing when watching anime, then this is not for you. There is action, but it thins out quite fast when nearing episodes 8, 9, 10. But to guys who love the likes of NGE, Bokurano, Serial Experiments Lain and such, Ergo Proxy is one more epic addition to your list.
Story: 10/10
The story is easily 10/10. Set in a seemingly standard dystopian Earth setting, the storyline is spread among a few core characters, each a very complicated story to tell. All seemingly separated, yet connected. Mystery is omnipresent while watching. At any pointof time, there are bound to be loads of questions flying around in your head. Throughout the anime, these questions are slowly given hazy hints to their answers, yet sometimes confusing evidence appear, and the characters themselves are as confused as the viewer. One bad thing one may point out is the lack of a true blue explanation of every loose thread by the end of the series, but hey, what's the point of watching such anime if EVERY small detail is explain explicitly?


Art: 9/10

For an anime of such genre, to have animation that rival that of other famous, mainstream anime is simply unbelievable. The environment designs are pure beauty, the movements are fluid, the action is realistic and the characters' emotions are portrayed powerfully with the strong art style used. The constant dystopian-dark theme may be the only flaw in this aspect.


Sound: 9/10

The best part of the sound aspect is the voice-acting. Every character had a very much appropriate and supportive voice that backed their emotions and character developments up.


Character: 10/10

The characters are wonderfully designed, together with the outstandingly complex storyline, gives a huge amount of character development throughout the series. They connect with the viewer closely, yet maintaining a "so-close-yet-so-far" connection due to the mystery surrounding them. There aren't many core characters, but each one is very holistically developed, at a good pace relative to other characters, and they grow into an extremely strong cast altogether. The storyline is fluidly powered by their combined decisions and actions, and their emotions fuel the viewers endlessly. Their dialogue is another thing that differentiates Ergo Proxy from other anime. When watching Ergo Proxy, you feel like you are a phantom in their world watching them, because none of the dialogue responds explicitly to viewer wants. The anime doesn't feel like an anime, more like a documentary, a true story recorded on film. The characters don't say unnecessary lines put in just to let viewers know certain details, no. The characters say exactly what they should say at that point of time, without knowing that us viewers are watching them. Awesome.


Enjoyment: 7/10

This may be the only part of Ergo Proxy not really up to the usual mark. But the reason is more or less justified. To have dialogue take place of most of the action in other anime and completely 0 fan service, it's hard to say that it has extremely high entertainment value. I guess many would even fall asleep watching certain episodes.


Overall: 9/10

In conclusion, if u like wanna get a shitload of mindfuck, get a shitload of Ergo Proxy.

Pure entertainment movies versus movies that challenge you to think (meaning the kind that win Academy Awards). Transformers vs. The King's Speech. Usually, a movie falls more easily into one or the other. Anime is no different. Your Guilty Crowns and Fate/Stay nights fall into the former. Ergo Proxy, on the other hand, falls into the latter.
There is very little action in Ergo Proxy in comparison to the other animes I have watched. With the exception of Proxies doing battle and Re-l Meyer showcasing her excellence with a shotgun, the majority of the story is spent investigating and exploring the back-story of Ramdeau, the Proxiesand why the world is the way it is. The story grabs you from the beginning with leaving so much a mystery. As one piece falls into place, an entire portion of the puzzle you were unaware of reveals itself, half-obscured. It is a very somber tale that left me feeling a bit depressed at times (as good animes seem to do).\n\n
Ergo Proxy is a thinking person's anime. The ending can seem a bit of a letdown and Episodes 10 through 20 appear to be a slog to quite a few people, but I found them enjoyable. I'm one of those individuals who can enjoy Transformers for what it is and still tear up when King George VI shouts "Because I have a voice!" in The King's Speech.

This is a very hard anime to rate.  Ergo Proxy is both masterpiece and frustrating to watch at the same time.  If you make it to the end and are actually able to understand everything, or at least most of what's going on, you will be left in awe at how incredible it really is.  It's probably the most thought provoking anime I've watched.  And unlike Evangelion, it actually answers most of the questions, though often in roundabout ways, or otherwise it infers things or deliberately leaves it to the imagination.
So, to start it off, the story.  Right away, youare thrown into a utopian society with highly advanced technology.  Autoreives, the machines manufactured by humans, run pretty much everything.  They look and act like humans but are devoid of any emotion.  The Cogito virus gives them something like a soul, and they find emotions.  Autoreives infected with this virus often try to find out why they were created or why they serve their masters, but these emotions are not to be allowed and they are destroyed.  The people in this society are driven to become model citizens, that serve the city and its people perfectly.  If you ask me, they all act like robots themselves.  I'd go deeper into that, but I don't want this to be too much of a philosophical discussion.  This is just one of many philosophical questions posed here.


Re-l Mayer is our heroine, and right away she seems a bit different, with her strange eyeshadow.  She is the granddaughter of the administrator, kind of like the head of a council in the city, and also an investigator.  She is investigating the Cogito virus and comes across some sort of monster, and her journey to find the truth begins.


Vincent Law works on autoreives and is an acquaintance of Re-l's that seems to have a bit of a crush on our heroine.  He is an immigrant and is working toward citizenship in this utopian society.  But he keeps popping up where the trouble is, like it's following him around.  Re-l and eventually he himself begin to wonder why all of this trouble seems to spring up around him.


In the first few episodes, a large part of the story, the character introductions, and just an overwhelming amount of information is just dropped on you.  It's very fast paced and very little of the literally hundreds of questions you have are answered.  After that, bits and pieces of what's going on are revealed and the pace of the show slows down.  I can understand why some people might give up on this, because it gets pretty confusing and most of the time you will just be wondering what is going on.  But, most of the questions are eventually answered, and I don't think there are any major parts they leave out.  Well, maybe one in the last episode, but I think they meant to leave that open.  For someone watching it for the first time, I'd like to say that there is a weird kind of game-show episode in the middle.  Pay attention!!!!  Answers to a lot of questions will be here.  Other than that, there are a lot of places that don't really seem important, but they are.  It may take a second watch to pick up on some of those though.


I'll go ahead and say a bit about the characters next, since I already introduced Re-l and Vincent.  The other main character in the story is Pino, and autoreiv infected with the Cogito virus, so she is a lot like a real little girl.  I can't say too much about any of the characters though cause I think I'd probably give away too much, and may start to rant about philosophy again.  I will say that all of the major characters show significant development throughout the series.  And it is done very well.


The art is excellent.  The animation is very smooth, from simple scenes to action scenes and everything in between.  The art is gorgeous.  The character designs are a bit different, but fitting with the show, and are also done very well.  The backgrounds are rich in detail and are just beautiful.  Everything is really top notch here.


Sound is good.  The opening and endings are good, I liked the songs in both.  There wasn't much music in the show, but the sounds were done pretty well.


I guess that would bring me to the enjoyment factor.  It's really hard to rate.  For most of the series I was plainly frustrated with how little information was revealed for how many questions the show posed.  Even so, I couldn't stop watching it.  Even after one episode of just asking "what the hell is going on?" I just wanted to watch the next one.  It just kind of draws you in.  I think this is mostly due to the excellent characters, but you also want to know more about what is going on in this world.  As I said at the beginning, it was frustrating but at the same time it was a masterpiece that can really only be seen for what it is once you have finished it.  While I was watching the show, I probably would've given a 5 or 6 for enjoyment because of the frustration, but I'd end up giving it an 8 or 9 in the end.  After all, it kept me wanting for more.


To conclude, everything about this show was really pretty incredible.  The characters especially shine.  There is a great amount of philosophy there and it really makes you think about a great many things.  It is difficult to rate.  As frustrated as I was through the show, after I finished it, I looked back and was simply amazed by the sheer mass of the show.  I'm giving it a 9, but I may watch the show again and upgrade it to a 10.  Even now, I'm not sure it doesn't deserve a 10, but I didn't enjoy it quite as much as some shows, so I don't think I can give it a perfect score.  So, it's a 9.


PS I have to apologize since this review may be a bit confusing itself.  I was trying really hard to put the show into words with out giving away too much of the show or ending up on a huge rant on philosophy.  And I like huge rants on philosophy.  Hopefully I was able to stay on track fairly well.
